title.narrative: SWE-2010-52 Future prospects in a changing world: Evaluation and improvement of East African seaweed farming for increased productivity and susta
SWE-2010-52 Future prospects in a changing world: Evaluation and improvement of East African seaweed farming for increased productivity and susta

description.narrative: East African seaweed aquaculture has the potential to increase livelihood alternatives in poor coastal areas and provide high valued products. Further development is required to ensure socio-economic sustainable farming practices, increase production and mitigate environmental impact. The aims of the proposed project are to a) quantify the genetic diversity in both the farmed, introduced, stock and native populations of Euchema and Kappaphychus in East Africa and relate this variation to growth and resistance to diseases and temperature changes and b) investigate if dispersal of introduced seaweeds can be an environmental threat in East Africa. The results will facilitate the improvement of seaweed farming outcome and provide a risk assessment system for transfer of exotic seaweed genotypes for cultivation. It will also strengthen the capacity for population genetic work in the region.

East African seaweed aquaculture has the potential to increase livelihood alternatives in poor coastal areas and provide high valued products. Further development is required to ensure socio-economic sustainable farming practices, increase production and mitigate environmental impact. The aims of the proposed project are to a) quantify the genetic diversity in both the farmed, introduced, stock and native populations of Euchema and Kappaphychus in East Africa and relate this variation to growth and resistance to diseases and temperature changes and b) investigate if dispersal of introduced seaweeds can be an environmental threat in East Africa. The results will facilitate the improvement of seaweed farming outcome and provide a risk assessment system for transfer of exotic seaweed genotypes for cultivation. It will also strengthen the capacity for population genetic work in the region.
